key_title: Key to the species of Kunzea

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Myrtaceae

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Myrtaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Jeanes, J.A. (1996). Myrtaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plant prostrate and trailing; leaves ovate to orbicular; fruit fleshy; west and south-west only
Plant erect or spreading (except in prostrate, alpine K. muelleri); leaves terete to narrowly elliptic; fruit a dry capsule
Plant prostrate or procumbent; leaves terete, margins involute; flowers yellow; alps and subalps
Plant erect; leaves linear to narrowly elliptic; flowers never bright yellow; lowland to montane
Leaves 1–4 mm long; flowers pink or purple, in small terminal heads
Leaves usually more than 4 mm long; flowers cream or white, crowded in upper leaf axils or on leafy side branches (rarely a spike of red flowers)
Flowers red, in dense spikes; capsules more than 6 mm diam.; leaves fringed with silky white hairs; cultivated plants
Flowers cream or white, not in spikes; capsules less than 6 mm diam.; leaf margins not distinctly fringed with hairs
Leaves 1–1.5 mm wide, concave above, keeled below; flowers more or less sessile; all filaments longer than petals
Leaves 1–4.5 mm wide, more or less flat; flowers on pedicels 3–6 mm long; at least some filaments shorter than petals
Flowers forming long, leafy racemes in upper axils; leaves linear-elliptic to linear-oblanceolate; pedicel and hypanthium with appressed hair; bark on young branches fibrous (not peeling)

Flowers crowded in upper leaf axils or on leafy side branches; leaves oblanceolate, obovate or linear-lanceolate, or if ever linear-elliptic then bark on young branches peeling and hairs on pedicel and hypanthium not as above
Hypanthium 2–2.3(–2.5) mm long; bark on young branches fibrous-corky; plants very twiggy, often root suckering; exposed sites near tops of ridges east of Bairnsdale
Hypanthium (2.5–)2.7–3(–3.3) mm long; bark on young branches peeling
Stamens usually 50–64, those opposite sepals mostly longer than petals; foothill forests to subalpine woodland, sometimes associated with rocky slopes or outcrops
Stamens usually (20–)25–32(–35), those opposite sepals mostly shorter than petals; foothill forests
Pedicel (0.5–)1–2.5(–3) mm long; leaves usually linear-oblanceolate or linear-elliptic and less than 2 mm wide; Yarra River and south-east suburbs of Melbourne
Pedicel (3–)4.5–5.2 mm long; leaves obovate or oblanceolate, usually more than 2 mm wide; widespread in forest east of Melbourne
